posts.author: Rachel Delia Benaim
posts.text:
Tropical Storm Nate Hammers Gulf Coast; More Than 60,000 Without Power in Mississippi, Alabama By Rachel Delia Benaim and Sean Breslin Oct 8 2017 06:00 AM EDT weather.com Tens of thousands lost power along the Gulf Coast as Tropical Storm Nate made landfall. Major flooding was seen overnight in Biloxi, Mississippi, and Mobile, Alabama. Numerous tornadoes were reported on the east side of the storm. No injuries or deaths have been reported in the U.S. 
Tropical Storm Nate continued its onslaught of the Gulf Coast Sunday morning, bringing major storm-surge flooding to Biloxi and Mobile while knocking out power to more than 60,000 homes and businesses across the region. The first hurricane to make landfall in Mississippi since Hurricane Katrina in 2005, Nate's powerful surge flooded several of the resorts and casinos along Mississippi's coast. The storm triggered flooding along sections of U.S. 90, according to the Mississippi Department of Transportation. In the hour preceding the storm's second landfall, water levels exceeded 4 feet above normal along the coast of Mobile, Alabama. Toppled trees damaged several homes in the city as winds increased, and a billboard was blown down near the local airport, the National Weather Service reported. (MORE: Get the Latest Forecast for Nate ) Currently, some 10,000 customers in southern Mississippi are without power due to the storm, according to the Mississippi Power Customers online management tool , and more than 55,000 are without power in Alabama early Sunday morning, Alabama Power reported. The storm also led to several reports of tornadoes on the east side of the storm, according to the NWS, and in Alabama, waterspouts were spotted off the coast. One confirmed waterspout moved ashore in Gulf Shores, Alabama, but no damage or injuries were reported. 
Prior to landfall, the storm raced toward the coast at 28 mph – the fastest recorded forward motion of a hurricane in the Gulf of Mexico, according to the NWS. 
Pensacola International Airport in Florida closed at 6 p.m. local time Saturday and will remain closed through Sunday. Mobile Regional Airport closed at 4 p.m. Saturday but officials hope to reopen Sunday around noon. Mississippi 
As high tide coincided with some of Nate's worst storm surge early Sunday morning, water was pushed ashore in massive quantities, flooding the parking deck of the Golden Nugget casino as well as parts of U.S. 90 near the coast. 
"It kind of surprised us," Mike Kovacevich, who lives two blocks north of U.S. 90, told Biloxi officials on their Facebook page, as reported by the Associated Press. "We didn't expect to be this deep. It come in pretty good — a lot of water." 
President Trump approved the emergency declaration for Mississippi on Saturday evening shortly as Nate closed in on the state. 
The city of Biloxi announced a curfew for residents lasting from 7 p.m. Saturday local time until 9 a.m. Sunday. 
State officials said they plan to open 11 shelters for evacuees Saturday and will run buses for residents who are unable to drive. 
Mississippi Power said Saturday it secured the assistance of up to 800 crew members , WLOX.com reported, and Singing River Electric crews are ready to restore power, if and when needed. Louisiana 
Local officials have urged residents to take the storm seriously. Gov. John Bel Edwards urged residents on Thursday to be "where they need to be by 3 p.m." Saturday evening, considering the speed at which the storm moved toward the coast. 
"This is a dangerous storm," Edwards said. "We have to make sure we are not taking it lightly." 
Evacuation orders were expanded Friday in Louisiana. In Jefferson Parish, mandatory evacuations were ordered in Lafitte , according to WWL-TV. Evacuations were also ordered in part of St. Bernard Parish located outside the levee protection system on Thursday, the AP reported. 
Officials in Grand Isle, a barrier island south of New Orleans, issued a voluntary evacuation for residents. Other voluntary evacuations were issued for parts of Lafourche and St. John parishes, WWL-TV also said. 
A curfew will begin at 10 p.m. Saturday in St. John Parish, ending at 5 a.m. Sunday, local time. 
Evacuations were ordered Friday for the Venetian Isles, Lake Catherine and the Irish Bayou areas outside of the New Orleans' levee protection system, and a mandatory curfew was ordered by New Orleans Mayor Mitch Landrieu beginning at 7 p.m. local time Saturday, ending Sunday at 6 a.m. 
Landrieu said flood-prone underpasses in New Orleans would be blocked to traffic. 
On Friday, Landrieu said 109 of the city's 120 pumps, or 92 percent, were working, while 26 backup generators were in place and ready to go. "Since early August, we have made substantial progress," New Orleans Mayor Mitch Landrieu told reporters Thursday. "Right now this storm should not bring us anything that we're not prepared to handle," Landrieu said Saturday. Alabama 
Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey also declared a state of emergency Thursday in order to free up personnel and resources in case responders need to be dispatched for any storm-related activity, the AP reported. 
The city of Gulf Shores issued evacuation orders Saturday for areas of West Beach Boulevard. 
Shelters were opened ahead of the storm to provide refuge to evacuees or those with nowhere else to go. The Rachel Patterson Elementary School opened its doors Saturday in Atmore, and the Robertsdale Coliseum opened in Baldwin County. Local news is keeping an updated list here .

posts.author: Jonathan Belles
posts.text:
A Northern Gulf Coast Hurricane Landfall in October or November is Quite Rare By Jonathan Belles Oct 4 2017 05:30 PM EDT weather.com Story Highlights As hurricane season begins to wind down, the threat of a hurricane lessens for some parts of the Gulf Coast. Cold fronts often push tropical systems toward Florida and away from Texas and Louisiana in October and November. Overall tropical activity dwindles through the end of the year. 
Three tropical storms and two hurricanes occur every year, on average, in the entire Atlantic Basin in the final third of hurricane season, according to the National Hurricane Center, but the focus for landfalls begins to shift eastward as seasons change. Hurricanes along the western and northern Gulf Coast become rare as daylight fades and trees begin to change colors. 
Only 15 named storms or hurricanes have had direct impacts on the Gulf Coast or Florida in October since 1950, and numbers steeply drop to two such systems in November. This averages out to be roughly one named storm landfall from Texas to Florida every four or five years. 
Of those, just four tropical systems have made landfall along the Texas or Louisiana coast, two of which made landfall in the first week of October. 
(MORE: Hurricane Central | Latest on the Tropics ) 
By October, the formation zones of tropical storms and hurricanes typically shift west toward the western Caribbean Sea, eastern Gulf of Mexico and far western Atlantic Ocean as the "Cabo Verde" portion of the hurricane season, featuring development of African easterly waves in the eastern Atlantic Ocean, fades. 
(MORE: How a Borderline La Niña Could Impact the Rest of the Atlantic Hurricane Season ) 
Autumn cold fronts are a saving grace for much of the western and northern Gulf Coast during October and more into November. Cold fronts routinely sweep developing tropical storms and hurricanes out of the Gulf, pushing them northeastward and out to sea. 
The cold fronts have to be well timed, however. The western Gulf can still be struck by hurricanes that come in between cold fronts. The frequency of cold frontal passage (also known as fropa) increases from October into November. 
Of course, when one location has a better fortune, somewhere else has to pay for it. 
Many Floridians consider October to be the peak of the hurricane season due to the increased number of hurricane strikes in that month, even though the peak of the season for the entire basin occurs in September. 
(MORE: Where the October Hurricane Threat is the Greatest ) 
From 1851 to 2016, 32 hurricanes made a Florida landfall in October, dwarfing the state with the second-highest number of October landfalls : Louisiana, with nine. 
By November, waters are cooling off and the atmosphere is becoming more hostile to tropical weather systems. Dying cold fronts often provide enough spin and moisture to kick-start late-season tropical storms. The most favorable conditions are found in the western Caribbean Sea and southwestern Atlantic, which is often where cold fronts lose their strength. 
According to NOAA's best track database, there have been 36 Atlantic tropical cyclones of at least tropical storm strength in November from 1950 through 2015. Twenty of those became hurricanes. 
In the period of record from 1851 to 2014, no tropical storm or hurricane has impacted the western Gulf Coast from Texas to Mississippi in the month of November. 
Since 1851, Florida has been impacted by eight tropical storms and hurricanes in November. The only other states with more than one November impact were also in the Southeast: Alabama, Georgia and North Carolina. 
Typically, November tropical systems follow the upper-level flow and cold fronts northeastward into the Atlantic Ocean.

posts.title: Winter Storm Aiden the First Snow of the Season in Denver; Travel Hassles in Wyoming, Colorado, Nebraska Panhandle - The Weather Channel
posts.text:
Winter Storm Aiden the First Snow of the Season in Denver; Travel Hassles in Wyoming, Colorado, Nebraska Panhandle Oct 9 2017 08:30 AM EDT weather.com Winter Storm Aiden is bringing the first accumulating snow of the season to Denver. Snow has already prompted an interstate closure in southeast Wyoming. Scattered power outages, broken tree limbs and poor travel conditions are potential impacts. 
Winter Storm Aiden is bringing the first snow of the season to the Denver metro area, but its heavy, wet snow to parts of Wyoming, Colorado and western Nebraska may trigger scattered power outages, not to mention travel headaches in the region. 
Precipitation changed over to snow just after midnight Monday morning in the city of Denver. Already, 2 inches of wet snow accumulation was measured at the National Weather Service office in Boulder, Colorado, early Monday, as well as near the suburb of Arvada on the northwest side of the Denver metro. 
Five inches of snow had accumulated in about nine hours through early Monday morning in Genessee, Colorado, in the Jefferson County foothills. 
In Wyoming, a stretch of Interstate 80 from east of Rawlins to Cheyenne was shut down early Monday morning due to dangerous winter driving conditions, according to the Wyoming Department of Transportation . 
( IMPACTS: Interstate Shut Down in Wyoming From Aiden Snow ) 
Up to 4 inches of snow had already accumulated in Wheatland, Wyoming, and 5.2 inches of wet snow was measured at the National Weather Service office in Cheyenne, Wyoming. 
Elsewhere in Wyoming, 6 inches of snow was measured on Casper Mountain, 8 inches of snow was estimated in Park County, and up to 5 inches was estimated in Yellowstone National Park, according to the NWS-Riverton, Wyoming, office. 
Some light accumulations prompted the closure of the Needles Highway in South Dakota's Custer State Park for a time Sunday. 
This is the first named winter storm of the season, although parts of the Rockies have seen multiple rounds of snow since September, including a blizzard last week in Montana . 
(MORE: How Winter Storms Are Named ) 
Aiden will be a quick-hitting winter storm, partially spawned by a southward dip in the jet stream sweeping into the Rockies. The cold air supplied by that jet stream dip, combined with an upslope northeast surface wind flow, is producing the snow along the Interstate 25 corridor, including in Denver and Cheyenne, Wyoming, as well as parts of the High Plains of western Nebraska and eastern Colorado. 
(MORE: 2017-18 Winter Storm Names ) Forecast Timing and Impacts 
The National Weather Service has issued winter storm warnings from southeastern Wyoming into Colorado. Winter weather advisories are also posted in other parts of Wyoming and Colorado, along with a small part of the Nebraska Panhandle. 
Timing Monday Morning/Afternoon: Snow, possibly heavy, continues to affect Colorado, along with far northern New Mexico and far southeastern Wyoming. Gusty winds continue on the plains. Monday Night: The winter storm will wind down, but some patches of light snow may linger in southeastern Colorado and northeastern New Mexico. 
Forecast Snow Amounts and Impacts Up to 6 inches of total snow is possible along the Interstate 25 corridor, including in Denver and Cheyenne, Wyoming. Heavier amounts are expected in the foothills west of Denver and in the Palmer Divide, along with the Snowy Range in Wyoming. Up to a foot of total snow (locally more) will be possible in those areas. Given trees in lower elevations still have their leaves, the wet snow, in combination with gusty winds, could result in scattered power outages and some broken tree limbs. For Denver, the National Weather Service said bridges and overpasses along the Interstate 25 corridor will be most prone to slushy accumulations. 
This will be Denver's earliest first snow of the season since 2012. Last year's first measurable snowfall in the Mile High City didn't occur until Nov. 17. The long-term average first measurable snow of the season in Denver is Oct. 18. 
The good news: this blast of wintry weather will not hang around for long. High temperatures will warm back into the 60s and possibly lower 70s by mid- to late week in Denver.

posts.author: Chris Dolce
posts.text:
For First Time Since 2005, Four Hurricanes Make U.S. Landfalls in One Season By Chris Dolce and Jonathan Erdman Oct 8 2017 08:15 AM EDT weather.com Story Highlights Four different hurricanes have made a U.S. landfall in 2017. This is the first time as many as four hurricanes have made a U.S. landfall since 2005. 
Hurricane Nate was the fourth hurricane to landfall in the United States in 2017, the first time that's happened in a single hurricane season in over a decade. 
(FULL COVERAGE: Hurricane Central ) 
Nate made landfall around 7 p.m. CDT Oct. 7 near the mouth of the Mississippi River as a Category 1 hurricane, then made its final landfall near Biloxi, Mississippi, just after midnight Oct. 8. 
Together with a trio of Category 4 hurricane landfalls in less than a month's time from late August through late September, this is now the first time since the record-smashing 2005 hurricane season there has been as many as four U.S. landfalls in one season, all occurring within 45 days from Aug. 25 through Oct. 8. 
That 2005 season featured five U.S. landfalling hurricanes: Cindy, Dennis, Katrina, Rita and Wilma. 
( MORE: Ten Most Extreme Atlantic Hurricane Seasons in the Satellite Era ) 
The previous season, 2004, also featured five U.S. landfalls, including the infamous Florida four of Charley, Frances, Ivan and Jeanne. 
According to NOAA's Hurricane Research Division , only 14 other years featured at least four U.S. hurricane landfalls in the same season: 
( Note: A correction was made to the statistics below to include landfalls in Hawaii since 1900, in Puerto Rico since 1898 and in the U.S. Virgin Islands since 1917, when each first became U.S. territories.) 6 landfalls: 1985, 1916, 1886 5 landfalls: 2005, 2004, 1933, 1893 4 landfalls: 1964, 1959, 1909, 1906, 1888, 1869, 1852 
As you can see above, 2017 was only the third season in the last 50-plus years to have this happen. The Three Category 4 U.S. Landfalls of 2017 
Hurricane Maria made landfall with winds of 155 mph on September 20 in Puerto Rico. 
In the weeks before Maria, hurricanes Harvey and Irma made landfall at Category 4 intensity with 130 mph winds on August 25 in Rockport, Texas, and September 10 in the Florida Keys, respectively. 
Winds for a Category 4 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale range from 130 mph to 156 mph. Winds of that strength are capable of causing catastrophic damage. The scale does not factor other major hazards from hurricanes such as storm surge and flooding rainfall. 
The landfall of Harvey and Irma at Category 4 strength was already a historic event, marking the first time two Atlantic hurricanes struck the U.S. in the same year . With Puerto Rico taking a direct hit from Maria, the U.S. has now endured landfalls from three Category 4 hurricanes. 
Category 4 or stronger Atlantic hurricane landfalls in the Lower 48 are a rare occurrence, with only 27 documented since 1851 , including Harvey and Irma. Three of those 27 landfalls were Category 5 hurricanes.

posts.author: Brian Donegan
posts.text:
Hurricane Ophelia to Brush the Azores This Weekend; May Affect Ireland Next Week as a Powerful Post-Tropical Storm By weather.com meteorologists Oct 13 2017 05:00 PM EDT weather.com Ophelia is the 10th straight Atlantic named storm to become a hurricane. This ties the record for the most consecutive Atlantic named storms to reach hurricane strength. Ophelia is expected to brush by the Azores this weekend. Ophelia will then become a post-tropical cyclone early next week and could bring high winds to parts of Ireland and the U.K. 
Hurricane Ophelia remains a Category 2 hurricane and is no threat to the United States, but is expected to brush parts of the Azores this weekend. Ophelia will then bring a blast of strong winds early next week to Ireland and perhaps the United Kingdom as a powerful post-tropical low-pressure system. 
(MORE: Hurricane Central ) 
Hurricane Ophelia's forward speed has begun to increase, and it will continue to accelerate toward the east-northeast near or just southeast of the Azores this weekend. 
Depending on its exact track, tropical-storm-force winds are possible in the Azores by late Saturday or Saturday night. At a minimum, some outer rain bands and gusty winds could impact southeastern portions of the Portuguese archipelago this weekend. 
Ophelia is expected to produce total rain accumulations of 2 to 4 inches over the southeastern Azores through Saturday night, which could lead to flooding. 
At the same time, a cold front and moisture associated with Ophelia is expected to produce 1 to 3 inches of rainfall over the other islands of the Azores. 
(MORE: 2017 Atlantic Hurricane Season Now 8th Most Active in History ) 
Only 15 hurricanes have passed within 200 nautical miles of the Azores since 1851, according to NOAA's historical hurricane database . All of those occurred in August or September, except for Hurricane Fran in October 1973 and Hurricane Alex in January 2016 , which made landfall shortly after weakening to a tropical storm. 
The National Hurricane Center forecasts Ophelia to transition into a post-tropical cyclone by Monday – but with winds remaining at or above hurricane force – as it curls northeast well off the Iberian Peninsula (Portugal and Spain). 
(MORE: Where the October Hurricane Threat is the Greatest ) 
The post-tropical cyclone is then expected to pass near Ireland on Monday. 
Ophelia is expected to weaken some while it tracks near Ireland, but strong winds are becoming increasingly likely over portions of Ireland and the United Kingdom. 
This could bring a blast of high winds to the Emerald Isle beginning Monday. Portions of the United Kingdom could also be impacted by Ophelia's strong winds. 
Details on the severity of impacts in Ireland and the U.K. will depend on the exact track of the powerful low-pressure system in relation to those countries. 
Met Eireann has issued a yellow weather advisory for Ireland on Monday, as it notes that the remnants of Hurricane Ophelia have the potential to be a high-impact event in parts of the country. 
The U.K. Met Office has issued a yellow warning for wind on Monday for portions of northern Ireland, western Scotland, Wales and far western England. The warning indicates that some transportation delays are possible, and there is a slight chance of power outages, damage to buildings and large waves. 
Check back with weather.com for additional details on forecast impacts in Ireland and the U.K. Record-Tying 10th Consecutive Atlantic Hurricane 
Ophelia is the 10th consecutive Atlantic named storm to become a hurricane in 2017. 
This ties the record for the most consecutive Atlantic named storms reaching hurricane strength, which also happened in three other years : 1878, 1886 and 1893, according to Dr. Phil Klotzbach , Colorado State University tropical meteorologist. 
There are a couple of caveats to this record, however. 
"Lee could easily be counted as two storms," tweeted Brenden Moses , a University of Miami hurricane researcher specializing in the historical hurricane database. 
After briefly becoming a tropical storm, Lee degenerated into a remnant low on Sept. 18 about halfway between west Africa and the Lesser Antilles. Four days later, Lee sprung back to life as a tropical cyclone and eventually strengthened to a Category 3 hurricane on Sept. 27. 
Moses later tweeted that if separated, there would be a tropical storm, then a separate hurricane, which would make the 10-straight-hurricane record invalid. This type of post-analysis occurs after every hurricane season, sometimes leading to the addition of previously unnamed storms or tweaking of tropical cyclone intensities. 
The other disclaimer about tropical cyclones before satellites were routinely used to examine the entire tropical Atlantic Basin in 1966 is that some tropical storms – even hurricanes – may have been missed that could have influenced any streaks, especially in the 19th century.

posts.author: Chris Dolce
posts.text:
Here's When Winter Weather Conditions Typically Arrive Where You Live By Chris Dolce Oct 12 2017 03:00 PM EDT weather.com Story Highlights Winter officially starts Dec. 21, but for many cities, snow and cold temperatures occur well before that time. Historical weather data in tandem with criteria from a winter severity index reveals when winter weather conditions typically arrive where you live. 
Winter officially begins on Dec. 21 this year, but depending on where you live, true winter weather conditions can begin well before this date or even after it passes. 
Climatologist Dr. Brian Brettschneider of the University of Alaska-Fairbanks compiled the map below which captures the median date for when the first winter weather conditions of the season have historically arrived in the United States and Canada. 
Brettschneider used an index called the Accumulated Winter Season Severity Index (AWSSI) to create the map using weather data over the past 40 years. 
For any given location, the start date of the winter, based on the AWSSI, is defined as when the first measurable snowfall (0.1 inches or greater) occurs, or when the first high temperature 32 degrees or lower is recorded. The start date is Dec. 1 for any location that does not see either prior to that date. 
As you would expect, the median date when northern climates historically see their first measurable snow or high temperature 32 degrees or lower is before winter officially begins. 
For parts of northern Canada and Alaska, the median date is long before the official start of winter, occurring in September or even earlier. 
Farther south, the median date for the arrival of the first winter weather conditions of the season is before Dec. 1 in a swath from the Northeast westward through the Midwest and into parts of the Rockies and Northwest. 
Winter starts Dec. 1 in much of the South, based on the AWSSI index criteria, since the median date of the first measurable snow or first high temperature 32 degrees or lower is after that date. In some years, parts of the South never see measurable snow or a high temperature 32 degrees or lower. 
(MORE: When the First Snow of the Season Typically Occurs ) 
During the course of the winter season, the AWSSI tracks the severity of winter weather conditions in real-time for several cities across the U.S. 
"The categories are site-specific ... because what constitutes a severe winter, say, in Washington D.C. or Atlanta would be considered mild in Chicago or Minneapolis ," said Dr. Barbara Mayes Boustead, co-creator of AWSSI and a forecaster at the National Weather Service in Omaha, Nebraska. 
The index takes into account the "intensity and persistence of cold weather, the frequency and amount of snow and the amount and persistence of snow on the ground ," said the Midwest Regional Climate Center. Wind and mixed precipitation, such as freezing rain, are not a part of the index. 
The index uses five categories – mild, moderate and average to severe and extreme – to rate the severity of winter weather at any given point in the season. 
You can track the AWSSI during the winter ahead at this link .

Wildfires Devastate Northern California (PHOTOS) Oct 13 2017 11:00 PM EDT weather.com 
At least 40 people have died due to aggressive wildfires in Northern California's Napa, Sonoma, Yuba and Mendocino counties. The fires have destroyed at least 5,700 homes and businesses as hundreds of firefighters attempt to stem the blazes which have burned more than 150 square miles. 
Fire officials say that it has been the deadliest week of wildfires in the state's history. 
An estimated 100,000 people have been chased from their homes and the Sonoma Sheriff's Department said they have received more than 1,000 missing-person reports. Officials have been able to track down more than half of those people so far. 
(MORE: The Latest on the Northern California Wildfires ) 
The Napa Valley fires spread quickly due to strong north to northeast winds from Winter Storm Aiden, according to weather.com senior meteorologist Jon Erdman . Winds are expected to increase again late Friday night into this weekend. 
The fires have burned businesses, including a hotel , wineries, a historic barn, a K-mart and homes at the Journey's End Mobile Home Park in Santa Rosa. 
We will continue to update the slideshow at the top of this page with the latest images, so please check back frequently.

posts.title: Sky turns red as winds blow in from south - The Weather Channel
posts.text:
Sky turns red as winds blow in from south By Brett Gibbons 1 of 11 Southport Blazing red sun as the sky turned an eerie orange captured on camera in Southport (Credit: Jayne Chloë Spencer's 12 year old daughter / Facebook) 
Red-hot air blowing soil particles northwards from Spain and Portugal are giving a strange eerie glow to skies over England and Wales. 
MORE: Wildfires kill at least 30 in Spain and Portugal 
Much of the country from the West Midlands and Wales, down to the south-west and south-east, is haunted by the sepia-tinted sky in advance of ex-hurricane Ophelia hitting the country later today. 
Strong winds from the south have been blowing remnants of the Iberian soil across much of southern England and Wales. Fine grains from the parched ground have helped form the sepia tinge to the air. 
Forecaster Dave Reynolds, of The Weather Channel, said: “Winds were strong over Iberia on Sunday, which has resulted in dust blown to the UK on a strong south to south-westerly flow. 
“This is a result of Ophelia positioned to the west of Portugal on Sunday and high pressure over the western Mediterranean. 
“Furthermore, and importantly, the cold front of Ophelia moved across southern Britain this morning and was very weak - this meant there was not much rain to wash the dust out. 
“Usually winds would veer away and fresher, clearer Atlantic air would come in behind a cold front - but this won’t happen until later today. As fresher air moves in, expect the colouration to gradually fade. 
“Much of the cloud at the moment is also at mid-levels. Lower and upper levels are fairly clear, which allows more sunlight to penetrate and, combined with the fairly high cloud base - 3,600 ft at Birmingham Airport - allows conditions to be bright at surface. 
“It’s worth checking car bonnets and car roofs for any dust - it’s most noticeable if there’s a little light rain. Anything more and it would get washed away.” The Weather Company’s primary journalistic mission is to report on breaking weather news, the environment and the importance of science to our lives. This story does not necessarily represent the position of our parent company, IBM. FEATURED CONTENT

posts.text:
UPDATES: Three dead as Ophelia wreaks havoc across Ireland By Brett Gibbons and Charlotte Smith 10 hours ago 00:22 Ex-hurricane Ophelia: Latest path of storm Detailed footage from Thursday September 21 reveals the latest path Hurricane Maria is forecast to take. 
Three people have been killed as hurricane-force winds from Storm Ophelia battered Ireland and the UK. 
A woman died when her car was struck by a falling tree as she was driving close to the village of Aglish in Waterford, Ireland, while a man was killed in a chainsaw accident as he tried to remove a fallen tree in Cahir, Co Tipperary. 
Another man has also died during Ophelia when a tree fell on his car, in Ravensdale, Dundalk, Ireland. 
Scores of homes were left without power, schools closed early, trees fell on to roads and bridges were shut on the UK mainland. 
Storm Ophelia is expected to hit the UK mainland at around midday, with flights grounded and a "danger to life" warning in place. 
Planes have been grounded at Manchester Airport, with 20 flights cancelled and passengers warned to check ahead. 
Ireland was braced for the worst of the weather, with schools closed and around 130 flights cancelled at Dublin airport. Expected weather patterns for Monday night (The Weather Company) 
Here's the latest updates from across the UK and Ireland. 
19:46: Official weather warnings are still in place this evening. CLICK HERE to see how Ophelia will affect the UK overnight. 
19:28: Multiple flights have made emergency landings in Britain today due to fumes in cabin related to ex-hurricane Ophelia. Up to 180 flights have now been cancelled, but Dublin Airport remains open. 
19:17: Enormous waves currently affecting Aberystwyth, Wales, as Opheila brings gusts of 80mph. 
18:46: Have a look at what the weather has instore for the remainder of the week: UK five-day weather forecast 
18:20: Highest wind speeds in Wales in so far have reached 89mph in Aberdaron. 
17:54: Ex-hurricane Ophelia to cause travel disruption for much of the evening rush-hour to some routes in the west and north of England, Wales and Scotland. Fallen trees and blocked lines expected to cause cancellations or up to 30 minutes delay. 
17:45: Watch pilot land plane amid Storm Ophelia in Dublin. 
MORE: Five-day forecast: Latest outlook for working week 
17:38: Ophelia's strongest winds are expected to affect Northern Ireland, north-west Wales, Isle of Man and south-west Scotland over the next few hours. Disruption is likely. 
17:11: Forecasters have said strong winds dragging up dust from the Saharan desert and smoke from wildfires in Iberia, as a result of ex-Hurricane Ophelia, were behind today’s eerie orange glow in the skies. However, a leading asthma charity has issued a ‘toxic air’ warning due to the high levels of dust. People with the respiratory illness is urged to stay indoors. 
15.41: Check out what's happening in Wales as Ophelia moves north-eastwards 
15.39: It's good to see that people can keep their sense of humour - and display their musical knowledge - despite the bad weather. 
15.29: There are reports that conditions are getting more potent in west Wales with towering waves recorded in the Irish Sea. 
15.01: A man has reportedly been killed in a chainsaw incident while trying to remove a fallen tree in Co. Tipperary, Irish Police have said. 
14.56: While Ireland and western Britain is battered by Ophelia, the south-east basks in temperatures in the low 20s C. 
14.55: The latest from forecasters at The Weather Channel. 
14.48: It looks like the winds are starting to affect the Irish Sea on the west coast of Wales. Officials at Aberdovey Lifeboat station in mid-Wales have issued the following message: " Winds this afternoon are forecast to gust up to violent storm force 11 locally, that's some of the strongest winds we've had here in years! 
"Please take care whilst out and about. Remember that although the waves will look impressive ,with local surf reports putting the wave height at five emtres or more, they're incredibly powerful and also contain debris such as rocks that they're hurling about. The best advice would be to stay well clear. #StaySafe #RespecttheWater " 
14.31: It seems like the strange weather conditions are now moving across Britain with the sepia-tinted sky now blanketing parts of Manchester. 
14.16: Flights are also disrupted from Edinburgh Airport. 
A spokesman said: "Due to the weather, the only disruption we are currently experiencing is to our Irish flights. 
"Aer Lingus have cancelled the rest of their flights for Monday, Ryanair, EasyJet and FlyBe are also experiencing some cancellations. 
"We would advise passengers flying to Ireland to check with their airline in advance of coming to the airport. All other flights are currently operating as normal to and from Edinburgh Airport." 
13.56: There's a risk of localised flooding in the south-west of England and the Environment Agency has urged pedestrians and motorists to be extra careful during the weather alert. 
13.50: A serious warning to avoid sea fronts and flood water from the Royal National Lifeboat Institute. 
13.35: High winds have ripped the roof from a building in Galway, southern Ireland. It appears the covering of a grandstand at a sports club has been blown away by Ophelia winds. 
13.15: Motorists have been warned to avoid unnecessary travel as Storm Ophelia batters parts of the UK. Remnants of the hurricane are set to hit Britain's west coast on Monday afternoon, with gusts of up to 80mph causing power cuts and bridge closures. 
Motorists have been warned about flying debris, fallen trees and large waves along coastal roads. 
The AA issued emergency advice to drivers to be prepared for disruption and road closures. Spokesman Vince Crane said: "Those in the worst-affected regions such as Ireland, west Wales, the North West and Scotland should avoid unnecessary travel."For those on the road, expect disruption and drive to the conditions. 
"This may mean slowing down so that sudden gusts don't blow you as far off course." 
13.10: Bill Clinton was forced to postpone a planned intervention in Northern Ireland's political stalemate because of storm Ophelia.The Press Association reported the former US president had been due in the region on Monday to meet warring political parties as they continued to struggle to reach a deal to restore the collapsed Executive.But the visit was called off at late notice due to the severe weather warnings. It is understood the visit may still take place on Tuesday. 
12.55: TV station RTE has reported one woman has died in south-east Ireland as a result of ex-hurricane Ophelia. It is believed a tree fell on a car in Waterford. 
12.48: Around 120,000 homes and businesses are now without power as Storm Ophelia hits Ireland. ESB has warned that more outages are expected and that repair operations will take several days.Gusts of 92mph (148kph) have already hit the south west coast and forecasters have warned that worse is yet to come. 
12.46: Belfast International Airport said the storm is having an impact, with both Ryanair and Easy Jet cancelling flights. The airport is expecting more cancellations. Anyone due to travel has been advised to contact their airline. 
12.33: Here's an interesting thought on the effects of Ophelia in Devon and Cornwall where a strange burning smell has been noticed. 
12.29: Winds are starting to blow in Ireland. Here's the latest gusts measured by Met Eireann and The Weather Channel. 
12.27: The red-tinted sun has provided some fantastic images. 
12.21: The storm is raging through southern Ireland with reports of trees being ripped down and blocking roads and other incidents of structural damage. 
12.00: Winds are picking up over the south coast of Ireland, according to the UK Met Office. 
11.49: Flights have been hit in Ireland. Cork Airport has advised of major disruption. 
11.29: The Met Office has warned that Ophelia will move northwards within the next 24 hours. 
11.27: The sun has a strange eerie glow this morning. Here is why. 
11.23: Ophelia is the 10th consecutive Atlantic named storm to become a hurricane in 2017. 
This ties the record for the most consecutive Atlantic named storms reaching hurricane strength, which also happened in three other years : 1878, 1886 and 1893. It is the furthest east that a major Atlantic hurricane system has been recorded. 
11.13: It's looking pretty wild in Ireland at the moment. 
MORE: Watch where Ophelia's winds will hit in the UK and Ireland 
11.05: The Met Office has updated its warning for high winds in the UK. 
11.02: More than 30,000 properties in the UK and Ireland now reported to be without power. Also new high gust of 120mph reported at Fastnet Lighthouse. 
11.00: Met Eireann has posted a summary of some of the strongest gusts in Ireland. 
10:57: Here's the expected track of Ophelia as it nears the Irish coast. The Weather Company’s primary journalistic mission is to report on breaking weather news, the environment and the importance of science to our lives. This story does not necessarily represent the position of our parent company, IBM. FEATURED CONTENT

St. Mary's Island, United Kingdom: 70 mph Dublin, Ireland: 64 mph Pembry, United Kingdom: 60 mph 
At least three people have died in the storm, the Associated Press reported. One person was killed Monday morning after a tree fell on a car in County Waterford, according to RTE. 
In addition to downed trees in Ireland, some roofs have been damaged or blown off . 
The Irish Times said at least 360,000 ESB Networks customers lost power in Ireland because of the storm. 
Irish authorities have ordered all schools in Ireland to be closed again on Tuesday, the Associated Press reported. 
Ophelia is striking Ireland and the United Kingdom as a post-tropical cyclone after the former hurricane lost its tropical characteristics in the northeast Atlantic Ocean on Sunday. 
Met Eireann has issued a red wind warning for all of Ireland on Monday. This is where sustained winds over 50 mph and gusts over 80 mph are expected, potentially causing structural damage and dangerous marine conditions. Downed trees and power lines are also likely. 
"There is potential risk to lives," Met Eireann noted in the warning. 
The U.K. Met Office has issued an amber warning for wind on Monday in Northern Ireland. The warning indicates that some transportation delays are possible, and there is a chance of power outages. 
A yellow warning for wind is in place across western Scotland, Wales and far western England. 
In the United Kingdom, Saharan dust and wildfire smoke that was drawn northward by Ophelia resulted in a brilliant sunrise on Monday morning. Recap: Farthest East Major Hurricane on Record 
For a time Saturday into early Sunday, Ophelia was a major hurricane ( Category 3 or stronger on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale ). 
That made Ophelia the farthest east Category 3 hurricane on record for the Atlantic Basin. The previous record was Hurricane Frances in 1980. 
Ophelia was also the sixth major hurricane of the 2017 Atlantic hurricane season. This means 2017 is tied for the most major hurricanes through Oct. 14 with 1933, 1961, 1964 and 2004, according to Dr. Phil Klotzbach , Colorado State University tropical meteorologist. 
Ophelia was also the 10th consecutive Atlantic named storm to become a hurricane in 2017. 
This ties the record for the most consecutive Atlantic named storms reaching hurricane strength, which also happened in three other years : 1878, 1886 and 1893, according to Dr. Phil Klotzbach . 
There are a couple of caveats to this record, however. 
"Lee could easily be counted as two storms," tweeted Brenden Moses , a University of Miami hurricane researcher specializing in the historical hurricane database. 
After briefly becoming a tropical storm, Lee degenerated into a remnant low on Sept. 18 about halfway between West Africa and the Lesser Antilles. Four days later, Lee sprung back to life as a tropical cyclone and eventually strengthened to a Category 3 hurricane on Sept. 27. 
Moses later tweeted that if separated, there would be a tropical storm, then a separate hurricane, which would make the 10-straight-hurricane record invalid. This type of post-analysis occurs after every hurricane season, sometimes leading to the addition of previously unnamed storms or tweaking of tropical cyclone intensities. 
The other disclaimer about tropical cyclones before satellites were routinely used to examine the entire tropical Atlantic Basin in 1966 is that some tropical storms – even hurricanes – may have been missed that could have influenced any streaks, especially in the 19th century.

thread.title: Puerto Rico Turns to Unproven Montana Company for Massive Power Restoration Job, But No One Knows Why
thread.title_full: Puerto Rico Turns to Unproven Montana Company for Massive Power Restoration Job, But No One Knows Why

posts.title: Puerto Rico Turns to Unproven Montana Company for Massive Power Restoration Job, But No One Knows Why
posts.text: Article Puerto Rico Turns to Unproven Montana Company for Massive Power Restoration Job, But No One Knows Why Published: | weather.com Oct 17 2017 8:58 PM Facing the destruction of almost its entire electrical grid after Hurricane Maria, Puerto Rico turned to a little-known Montana company to restore power rather than rely on a vast network of public power companies that usually comes to the rescue after disasters. Overall, progress has been slow and uneven, stoking concerns about whether the unproven company is up to the task – and raising questions about the irregular way in which the territorial government awarded the contract. Ordinarily, the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) provides money and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers oversees federally led recovery efforts after a disaster. Neither agency said it had a role in awarding or supervising the contract Puerto Rico awarded to restore its power lines. Concerns eased Monday after FEMA and the Army Corps belatedly announced a $240 million contract with Irving, Texas-based Fluor Corporation to take the lead in restoring transmission and distribution lines. But head-scratching continues over the curious and opaque manner in which heavily indebted Puerto Rico eclipsed FEMA, the Army Corps and a national network of public utilities – brimming with line workers and bucket trucks – by turning over such an immense responsibility to a two-year-old private company with few resources of its own. Typically, immediately after a disaster, the American Public Power Association – a public utilities trade group – emcees a conference call with its membership – 1,100 public utilities across the country – to get all the needed line workers and bucket trucks to the stricken area as soon as possible under what are called mutual aid agreements. For instance, the public power association facilitated the rapid deployment of many thousands of workers and their equipment to Texas and Florida after hurricanes Harvey and Irma struck. But the Puerto Rico Electrical Power Authority (PREPA) took a different route after Maria’s 155 mph winds decimated the island’s already-failing electrical grid on Sept. 20, leaving 3.4 million residents, hospitals and businesses without electricity – possibly for months. When the power association convened its conference shortly after Maria struck, PREPA told participants it wouldn’t need the network’s help because it had already contracted with Whitefish Energy Holdings LLC, a two-year-old consultancy, to spearhead the restoration efforts. Whitefish, having to subcontract almost all of the work, had recruited and deployed 160 of the 1,000 workers needed to do the job – 16 percent – three weeks after Maria struck. By then, coincidentally, 16 percent of the power grid has been restored. Last week, the effort saw reversals when a large number of people whose power had been restored lost it again when a transmission line tripped. “It’s a bit unclear why PREPA chose to go down that route, especially considering the offer was made to them for this mutual aid from the American Public Power Association that apparently wasn’t taken advantage of,” said Cathy Kunkel, an energy analyst with the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis, a non-profit that focuses on utility issues. It might have been “reasonable” to try to act quickly given the devastation caused by Maria, she said. However, she urged a federally appointed board overseeing Puerto Rico’s finances to obtain “a copy of that contract and do oversight on how that money was spent” to ensure that local ratepayers and U.S. taxpayers aren’t getting “ripped off.” The slow progress and questions surrounding the contract led the public power association to confirm Monday that Puerto Rico bypassed its vast resources by awarding the contract to Whitefish. “To date, PREPA has not requested aid from the Association; rather, it has engaged Whitefish to marshal the resources required to undertake power restoration,” the power authority stated. “Communications with PREPA and Whitefish have been difficult due to the telecommunications issues on the island.” The contract was reportedly awarded through a phone call placed in the days immediately after Maria hit. A PREPA employee who happened to have a satellite phone and phone number for Whitefish made the call, according a story published by E&E News , an independent news organization that focuses on energy and environmental issues. The employee had the phone number for Whitefish because PREPA had issued a request for proposals several days earlier to handle far-less-extensive damage caused by Hurricane Irma. It had grazed Puerto Rico two weeks earlier. Whitefish was one of only two companies to respond to the request, and so its phone number was handy after the power grid went dark because of Maria. But the timing left PREPA almost no time to vet the company. The E&E article was based on an interview with Ricardo Ramos, PREPA’s CEO, who told the publication, “The day that the Corps of Engineers showed up and offered the assistance, we immediately accepted because we knew that financially it was a better model. The benefit is that I don’t have to spend the remaining dollars that are needed for recuperating the system.” The Army Corps denied any role whatsoever in the awarding or execution of the Whitefish contract. Andrew Techmanski, who founded Whitefish in May 2015, told Bloomberg News in Puerto Rico that while other power companies were “afraid of the question of how are we going to get paid, Whitefish Energy was the company that actually made the leap of faith and was able to get over here." But PREPA spokesman Carlos Monroig Aceveda told weather.com that it had paid Whitefish “$2 million for the costs of mobilizing personnel and equipment,” adding that its contracts “are evaluated and awarded by the U.S. Corps of Engineers in coordination with FEMA, which disburses the money.” His statement that the Corps was supervising didn’t square with what Catalina Carrasco of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers told weather.com. She said the Corps “does not have any involvement with the contract between PREPA and Whitefish, adding in an email that the Corps “does not know how PREPA negotiated the contract. USACE does not know how PREPA is paying Whitefish. The contract is between PREPA and Whitefish. Corps of Engineers, did not negotiate, does not have ANY involvement between PREPA and Whitefish.” The emphasis was in the email. William Douglass, a spokesperson for FEMA, said the agency’s databases do not show any dealings with Whitefish, although he added that FEMA gives money to agencies like PREPA and those agencies sometimes give some money to a third party like Whitefish without FEMA necessarily knowing. Both FEMA and the Army Corps of Engineers have distanced themselves from PREPA’s contract with Whitefish. But FEMA has given PREPA $97 million to restore the power lines and PREPA could have used some of that money to pay Whitefish. FEMA announced Monday it was approving an additional $128 million for PREPA. PREPA itself is bankrupt, $9 billion in debt and currently generating no revenue. Even before hurricanes Irma and Maria struck, the island was experiencing frequent blackouts because of its aging power infrastructure. PREPA has existed for decades on financial vapors, resulting in critical maintenance being deferred and significant deterioration of its power generation, transmission and distribution infrastructure. Whitefish’s Techmanski was working in Puerto Rico and couldn’t be reached for comment, according to spokesman Brandon Smulyan, who was himself unable to answer basic questions about the company because he has only been working with Whitefish under a contract for the past week. For instance, he couldn’t say how many employees Whitefish has. Public records list Andrew Techmanski as the president and Amanda Techmanski, whom public records identify as a registered nurse, as the manager. Andrew Techmanski has an extensive background in power-line work, according to his LinkedIn profile and other public records. Smulyan said the young company is funded by two private equity firms – HBC Investments and Flat Creek Capital – both based in Dallas, Texas – and Brazil-based Comtrafo Transformers, which builds power transformers. “To date,” Smulyan wrote in an Oct. 11 email, “Whitefish has visited, assessed and created operational bases in Cayey, Arecibo, Salinas, Manati, and Ponce and San Juan. Whitefish has repaired structures, conductors and lines in Salinas and has built access roads to the southern portion of the Salinas 230kv line.” It also has contracted with JEA, a public utility serving the Jacksonville, Florida, area to send 41 line workers and service personnel to Puerto Rico. New York has sent a contingent of line workers, as well. Separately, the Army Corps of Engineers has put in a purchase order for 50,000 utility poles and 6,500 miles of cable. It also awarded a $35.1 million contract to West Chester, Pennsylvania-based Weston Solutions to install a 50 megawatt generator in Puerto Rico’s Palo Seco Power Plant. FEMA, the Army Corps of Engineers and the U.S. Department of Energy all have personnel on the ground coordinating power restoration efforts. Puerto Rico’s power infrastructure has been a concern for decades partly because it lies in the heart of a hurricane corridor. Previously, the territory’s power grid was ripped up by Hurricane Georges in 1998. After Georges, the Clinton administration gave $133 million to PREPA to fix the power grid and begin putting lines underground. In 2000, the administration issued a glowing report saying the improvements had “empowered” Puerto Ricans to “withstand even the most unreliable weather.” When Hurricane José struck Puerto Rico in 1999, the report said, the improvements left people, including PREPA officials, "confident" the island would not lose power. And it didn’t. But 18 years later, Maria utterly destroyed the grid and it remains unclear when – and for how long – power will be restored. MORE ON WEATHER.COM: Photos from Hurricane Maria

thread.title: Atmospheric River Will Bring Heavy Rain, Mountain Snow to the Pacific Northwest Through the Weekend - The Weather Channel
thread.title_full: Atmospheric River Will Bring Heavy Rain, Mountain Snow to the Pacific Northwest Through the Weekend - The Weather Channel

posts.title: Atmospheric River Will Bring Heavy Rain, Mountain Snow to the Pacific Northwest Through the Weekend - The Weather Channel
posts.text:
Atmospheric River Will Bring Heavy Rain, Mountain Snow to the Pacific Northwest Through the Weekend By Brian Donegan 20 hours ago TWC Canada 
A pattern change has taken shape over the Pacific Northwest that will bring an atmospheric river with soaking rain and mountain snow to Washington and Oregon this weekend. 
Right on cue as we progress deeper into fall, the Pacific jet stream is beginning to steer storm systems into the Pacific Northwest. 
The first Pacific storm pushed into the Northwest on Wednesday and will linger into Thursday. This system could also bring light amounts of rain to fire-ravaged northern California Thursday night. 
A more classic atmospheric river event is expected in the Northwest Saturday and Sunday. You can see each of these storms clearly on a Pacific-wide satellite image. 
An atmospheric river is a thin and long plume of moisture that stretches from the tropics or subtropics into higher latitudes – in this weekend's case, from the western Pacific Ocean to the northwestern United States. Current Satellite, Pressure and Atmospheric Moisture (The light blue lines are isobars, or lines of equal pressure. The more numerous and tightly packed the isobars, the stronger the winds. Deeper atmospheric moisture is shown by yellow, orange and red contours.) At a Glance The jet stream will steer a storm tapping an atmospheric river into the Northwest this weekend. Heavy rain and mountain snow will accompany this system. Flooding could become an issue in parts of Washington and Oregon by the weekend. 
Heavy rain accumulations are expected in the Pacific Northwest through this weekend, particularly on windward slopes of the Olympics and Cascades below snow-level and coastal ranges. Some minor river flooding could develop in the most flood-prone rivers in western Washington and Oregon by this weekend. 
Rainfall totals in these areas may approach 12 inches through Sunday when factoring in the rain that has already fallen plus what is to come. Rain and Snow Forecast 
Along the Interstate 5 corridor, more than 3 inches of rain could fall through Sunday, including the Seattle and Portland metro areas. 
In the highest elevations of the Cascades, heavy precipitation will fall in the form of snow, resulting in snowfall totals of a foot or more, particularly in Washington's North Cascades. Snow levels in these mountains may fall as low as 3,500 feet by Friday, but will then rise ahead of the next storm this weekend. 
The U.S. National Weather Service office in Seattle recommended clearing any leaves that may be clogging your storm drain. 
A break from this barrage of stormy weather will arrive in the Northwest early next week as the jet stream lifts northward and forces the storm track into Canada. posts.title: Facts about Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands – The Weather Channel
posts.text:
Facts about Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands By James Crugnale Oct 19 2017 12:00 AM EDT weather.com Story Highlights Puerto Ricans were officially recognized as citizens of the United States on March 2, 1917, when President Woodrow Wilson signed the Jones-Shafroth Act. The U.S. Virgin Islands, including the islands of Saint Croix, Saint John, and Saint Thomas, gained citizenship on Feb. 25, 1927. Residents of these territories can freely travel to the United States. 
The post-hurricane recovery that faces Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands has brought attention to the status of the U.S. territories. According to a September poll, only 54 percent of Americans knew that people born in Puerto Rico were U.S. citizens and were not citizens of their own country. As a humanitarian crisis continues to unfold for the islands, here's a look at some frequently asked questions about Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. What about Citizenship? 
Puerto Ricans were officially recognized as citizens of the United States on March 2, 1917, when President Woodrow Wilson signed the Jones-Shafroth Act. The population of Puerto Rico is 3.4M. 
Residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands have been citizens since Feb. 25, 1927, when Congress voted to bestow U.S. citizenship on them. A little over 100,000 people live on the islands. 
Puerto Ricans are also eligible for the military draft, and thousands served in both World Wars. 
The specific rights bestowed upon island territories is murkier. 
According to Slate's Doug Mack, a 1922 U.S. Supreme Court case, Balzac v. Porto Rico, found that the U.S. Constitution didn’t apply in totality to the territories : "only 'fundamental' rights were automatically in effect." Mack also found that the "Sixth Amendment right to a criminal trial by jury has not been held applicable in local courts in Puerto Rico." When did the territories become part of the United States? 
Following the Spanish-American War in 1898, Puerto Rico officially became a U.S. territory . Up until that time, Puerto Rico was a Spanish colony. 
Spanning from 1754 to 1917, the islands of St. Thomas, St. John and St. Croix were Danish colonies. The U.S. officially purchased the Virgin Islands from Denmark in 1917 for $25 million. Why aren't they states? 
Puerto Rico has generally voted against statehood in referendums that have been taken over the years. But most recently, in June, they voted in favor of statehood, with 97 percent supporting. However, the vote was criticized for its low turnout, with fewer than a quarter of eligible voters participating. To make their vote for statehood binding would take an act of Congress. According to a recent report by Reuters, it is unlikely that the Republican-controlled House of Representatives and Senate would affirm their statehood vote because the territory leans Democratic. The USVI held a referendum on political status back in 1993, with the majority voting to remain a territory. "However, issues of voter eligibility and an excessive number of options contributed to an insufficient percentage of the electorate participating in the vote," according to the Pacific Island Times . Can residents vote? 
While both Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands residents are ineligible to vote for the President of the United States, they do participate in presidential primaries and play a role in selecting the nominee of both major political parties. Similar to U.S. states, both islands elect local government officials and governors. Do they have Congressional representation? 
Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands both have a non-voting delegate in the House of Representatives. This delegate has many of the same responsibilities bestowed upon voting representatives – they're able to sit on committees and debate legislation. They are currently represented by Puerto Rico Resident Commissioner Jenniffer González-Colón (R) and USVI Delegate Stacey Plaskett (D). Do residents pay taxes? 
The majority of Puerto Ricans don't pay federal income taxes but they do pay other federal taxes, including Social Security and Medicare , according to the New York Times. They also pay import, export and commodity taxes.

thread.title: Health Crisis in Puerto Rico Is Likely Just Getting Started - The Weather Channel
thread.title_full: Health Crisis in Puerto Rico Is Likely Just Getting Started - The Weather Channel

posts.title: Health Crisis in Puerto Rico Is Likely Just Getting Started - The Weather Channel
posts.text:
Health Crisis in Puerto Rico Is Likely Just Getting Started By Jeffrey Kopman Oct 20 2017 07:15 AM EDT weather.com Puerto Rico is in the midst of a public health crisis. Access to clean water, electricity and medicine remains difficult. 
One month after Hurricane Maria Puerto Rico still finds itself in the middle of a public health crisis. Nearly 30 percent of citizens don’t have access to clean drinking water, 80 percent of the island is without power and dozens of hospitals are without electricity, according to the Government of Puerto Rico. 
“One of the biggest concerns is that people forget,” Dabney Evans, director of the center for humanitarian emergencies at Emory University in Atlanta, Georgia, told weather.com. “[For example,] we’re not talking so much about Houston. Attention dwindles away so quickly.” 
Attention may dwindle quickly, but the health crisis facing Puerto Rico likely won’t. Access to Clean Water 
Last week, a leptospirosis outbreak infected at least 10 people. The bacterial disease spreads to humans through drinking water that has been contaminated by animal urine, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 
“Without proper sanitation, which requires power for pumps and intact pipes, remaining surface water supplies can be contaminated with fecal material and animal urine (as surmised from current reports of leptospirosis infection in humans),” Barry J. Burton, D.O., visiting assistant professor, Disaster Medicine and Management, Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, told weather.com. 
That outbreak magnifies the biggest issue facing Puerto Rico right now: A lack of access to reliable, clean water. 
“An average weight, healthy human requires 90 to 120 ounces of water daily,” said Dr. Burton. “There is a lack of clean water from both packaged and native (streams and surface) water sources, because many native sources have been contaminated.” 
In addition to waterborne diseases like leptospirosis, lack of clean water can lead to dehydration, poor hygiene and unsterilized hospitals. 
Despite recent rumors, there has not been an outbreak of the foodborne illness cholera, and the CDC does not anticipate one, either. 
“Hospitals that are performing surgeries need clean water for three reasons: Drinking water, hand washing and surgical use,” Evans said. Overwhelmed and understaffed hospitals on the island continue to treat patients, but their jobs are even more difficult without clean water. 
The issue is compounded by another crisis: A lack of electricity throughout the territory. Access to Electricity 
Lack of electricity is a primary concern right now, explained Dr. Evans. “It means that [Puerto Ricans] will have a lot of difficulty keeping their food safe.” 
No electricity means no refrigeration, and that can lead to eating unsafe and contaminated foods. 
“Even if you use a generator, you may have difficulty keeping your food clean, which could lead to problems like foodborne illnesses,” said Evans. 
These illnesses can spread if residents ingest unsafe products. The CDC recommends people throw away food if it has an unusual odor, color or texture, has touched flood water or has not been properly refrigerated due to power outages — problems that are difficult to avoid in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria. Access to Medicine 
Power outages also provide a problem for any Puerto Ricans living with chronic conditions, and need electricity to keep their medications refrigerated, said Dr. Evans. “For example, a diabetic who takes insulin would need to keep their medication refrigerated.” 
The trouble extends beyond residential homes. It has impacted treatment centers, like dialysis centers, as well. 
“[Dialysis] is really important; it’s vital for the patient to continue living,” said Dr. Carlos Rivera, medical director of the Renal Center of San Sebastian, in a press release. “If the patient in end stage renal disease does not receive dialysis they could die in a couple of weeks.” 
“The DHHS and FEMA have been working hand-in-hand with the local providers to get them back on their feet,” SGT Thomas Calvert said in the press release. “The overarching aim is to get each dialysis facility to a self-sustaining status and back to normal operations as soon as possible.” 
While an emphasis has been placed on helping locals, especially those with chronic conditions, get back to normal, there are long-term concerns that will need to be addressed for the foreseeable future. Long-Term Threats 
“One of the biggest long term risks is a resurgence of Zika Virus,” said Dr. Evans. “Puerto Rico is a warm climate, and damage caused may also mean that the [leftover] water can’t drain off, and is left standing for a long period of time. This is a perfect breeding ground for mosquitoes. We know that Zika is in Puerto Rico, and my concern now is that there could be a lot of transmission and a resurgence.” 
Mosquito-borne disease outbreaks are concerning, but not all long-term problems are physical. 
“Hurricane survivors can face mental health issues like PTSD, anxiety, depression and substance use disorders long after rescue and recovery efforts end,” said Christine Guardino, psychology professor at Dickinson College in Carlisle, Pennsylvania. “For example, one study of survivors of Hurricane Katrina found that 31 percent of respondents showed symptoms of mood or anxiety disorders several months after the storm.” 
“Individuals who are personally injured or experience the death or injury of a loved one are especially likely to experience mental health issues. Forced relocation due to hurricane damage can also separate vulnerable individuals from their families, social services and health care facilities, contributing to distress and impairment,” Guardino added. “Early identification of those who have experienced trauma followed by mental health intervention can help to prevent long-term mental health problems.” What Needs to Be Done 
Dr. Evans stressed that the problems linked to Hurricane Maria won’t just go away, and that people can’t forget about Puerto Rico. 
“I think it’s important that we take action to provide an aid package to Puerto Rico as quickly as possible, and to continue to support these people,” Evans said. 
We’ve seen what these storms — Hurricanes Matthew, Irma and Maria — can do, Evans warned. “It is important to have a robust emergency response. We need to have the public health infrastructure to respond.”
